message: They're all 4GB boxes except the ops box, which is 1GB.
@dmishe Actually I think Linode is the best in terms of disk IO.

We've got 6 servers in total, on Rackspace.  One for ops stuff, trac, hudson, puppetmaster.  One for PostgreSQL and Solr.  One just for Redis.  And three web frontends that each host nginx, our Django/Eventlet stack, and Celery workers.

@dmishe I've got a bunch of experience using Rackspace before, we have a personal relationship with some people there, and I've seen some benchmarks showing better disk IO from Rackspace vs. many of the other providers.

You can always pass --noop to puppetd (puppetd --test --noop) to see what configuration changes *would* be made to server without actually making any changes. It acts as a dry run.
@ericflo oh, gotcha, i misread originally. so three web frontends, how do you distribute load across them? do you have a load balancer in front?
Right now it's super low tech: we have three IPs in our convore.com DNS A record listing, so clients pick one of the IPs at random.
This gives us load balancing, but not high availability.
At some point we're going to want to improve our availability story, so we'll set up proper balancing, but for now, multiple A records works like a charm!
